Title: The equivalence of two formulae for the Laplace—Beltrami operator
Content:
Let $M$ be a (pseudo-)Riemannian manifold with metric $g_{ab}$. Let $
abla_a$ be the Levi-Civita connection on $M$. It's well-known that the Laplace—Beltrami operator can be defined in this context as
$$
abla^2 = 
abla^a 
abla_a = g^{ab} 
abla_a 
abla_b$$
where $g^{ab}$ is the dual metric and repeated indices are summed. However, we also have the coordinate formula
$$
abla^2 \phi =  rac{1}{\sqrt{| \det g |}} \partial_a \left( \sqrt{| \det g |} g^{ab} \partial_b \phi ight)$$
which, as I understand, comes from using the formula for the Hodge dual. Without invoking advanced machinery, what is the easiest way to directly prove the equivalence of the two definitions? I can see that if the partial derivatives of $g_{ab}$ vanish, then 
$$
abla_{a} \left( g^{ab} 
abla_b \phi ight) = \partial_a \left( g^{ab} \partial_b \phi ight) =  rac{1}{\sqrt{| \det g |}} \partial_a \left( \sqrt{| \det g |} g^{ab} \partial_b \phi ight)$$
and in the general case it suffices to prove that
$$\Gamma^{b}_{\phantom{b}ab} =  rac{1}{\sqrt{| \det g |}} \partial_a \left( \sqrt{| \det g |} ight)$$
but then it is seems to be necessary to compute the derivative of a determinant. Is there a trick which can be used to avoid this calculation?
AcceptedAnswer:
For general relativity students I think this might be a reasonable proof. One needs to know that your second expression for $\nabla^2\phi$ (the one using $\sqrt{|\det g|}$) is independent of the choice of coordinates (*). For any point you can then choose coordinate system such that $\partial_a g_{bc}=0$ and the two formulas (as you notice) give the same result. (*) means (as you also notice - you just want us to restate it in a simpler language - and I'm not sure whether I succeed to do it) that if $u^a$ is a vector-valued density, i.e. if $u^a=v^a \sqrt{|\det g|}$ where $v^a$ is a vector field, then $\partial_a u^a$ is a density, i.e. $\partial_a u^a=f\sqrt{|\det g|}$ for some function $f$ (with $f$ independent of the choice of coordinates - which implies $f=\nabla_av^a$). If we really want to avoid differential forms then we can invoke Gauss theorem (in coordinates), notice that the flow of $u^a$ though a hypersurface is independent of the coordinates, and hence its divergence $\partial_a u^a$ is a well-defined (independent of coordinates) density. edit: here is (really the same, but) a bit more sensible argument why $f$ (see above) is independent of coordinates. If $\psi$ is a function with compact support then $\int (\partial_a\psi)\, v^a \sqrt{|\det g|} dx^1\dots dx^n$ is independent of the choice of coordinates, and it is equal to (by per partes) 
$$-\int \psi \partial_a\Bigl( v^a \sqrt{|\det g|}\Bigr)\sqrt{|\det g|}^{-1}\,\sqrt{|\det g|} dx^1\dots dx^n$$
which shows (by choosing $\psi$ with smaller and smaller support and with $\int\psi\sqrt{|\det g|} dx^1\dots dx^n=1$) that
$$f=\partial_a\Bigl( v^a \sqrt{|\det g|}\Bigr)\sqrt{|\det g|}^{-1}$$
is independent of coordinates.
